profile_data.summary: Neda has a PhD in computer engineering with focus on machine learning and computer vision from Southern Illinois University in 2015. Prior to graduation she studied big data for network videos at Nokia Bell Labs. Following her dissertation defense, she joined CCC Intelligent Solutions as a data scientist and developed the first deep learning model for the company that determines total vs repairable claims via photos of the accident. She is now serving as the director of data science leading multiple data scientist groups. The main goal of her team is to deliver AI products that disrupt the P&C industry

education.activities: IEEE, SIUIS (Southern Illinois University Innovative Systems)
education.description: An automatic bio-inspired key point detection and extraction strategy for classification of 2D and 3D images.

Thesis title: "3D Face Recognition using Discrete Cosine Transform(DCT)" . Thesis description:
My thesis focused on 3-D face recognition using the one- and two-dimensional Discrete Cosine Transform (DCT). A feature ranking based dimensionality reduction strategy was introduced to select the DCT coefficients that yield the best classification accuracies. Two forms of 3-D representation were used: point cloud and depth map images. These representations were extracted from the original VRML files in a face database and are normalized during the extraction process. Classification accuracies exceeding 97% are obtained using the point cloud images in conjunction with the 2-D DCT.

publications.name: Using the iCub Simulator to Study Perceptual Development: A Case Study
publications.description: In the present study, we assess the iCub simulator as a platform for investigating perceptual development in human infants. In particular, we evaluate the simulator as a quasi- realistic virtual environment for conducting object-perception experiments. As a case study, we describe our simulation of the perceptual-completion task, which measures infants’ perception of a moving, partially-occluded object. We present here two simulation studies. The first study replicates our previous findings, which demonstrate that increasing spatial competition in our eye-movement model results in increased attention toward the occluded object. We then extend these findings in a second simulation study by demonstrating that reducing the width of the occluder also increases attention toward the occluded object, though unexpectedly, only for low levels of spatial competition. We conclude by highlighting the value of the iCub simulator as a research tool for psychologists, and also by noting how our eye- movement model can be further improved and elaborated.

publications.name: On the inefficacy of Euclidean classifiers for detecting self-similar Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) messages
publications.description:
The Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) is an important
multimedia session establishment protocol used on the Internet.
Due to the nature and deployment realities of the protocol
(ASCII message representation, most deployments over UDP,
limited use of message encryption), it becomes relatively easy
to attack the protocol at the message level. To mitigate this, selflearning
systems have been proposed to counteract new threats.
However the efficacy of existing machine learning algorithms
must be studied on varied data sets before they can be successfully
used. Existing literature indicates that Euclidean distance based
classifiers work well to detect anomalous messages. Our work
suggests that such classifiers do not produce adequate results for
well-crafted malicious messages that differ very slightly from
normal messages. To demonstrate this, we gather SIP traffic
and minimally perturb it using 13 generic transforms to create
malicious SIP messages. We use th Levenshtein distance, L,
as a measure of similarity between normal and malicious SIP
messages. We subject our dataset â€” consisting of malicious and
normal SIP messages â€” to Euclidean distance-based classifiers
as well as four standard classifiers. Our results show vastly
different results for Euclidean distance-based classifiers on our
dataset than reported in current literature. We further see that
the standard classifiers are better able to classify an anomalous
message when L is small.

publications.name: Statistical analysis of self-similar Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) messages for anomaly detection
publications.description:
The Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) is an important
multimedia session establishment protocol used on the Internet.
Due to the nature and deployment realities of the protocol (ASCII
message representation, widespread usage over UDP, limited use
of encryption), it becomes relatively easy to attack the protocol
at the message level to launch denial of service attacks. To
mitigate this, self-learning systems have been proposed to detect
anomalous SIP messages and filter them. However, previous
works use datasets with large differences between the normal
and anomalous message. This gives high performance for existing
classification systems, including those based on Euclidean
distances. We present our analysis on a new dataset that has
minimal difference between normal and anomalous messages.
Our findings indicate that existing classification schemes behave
unsatisfactorily on our dataset. We demonstrate why this is
the case by statistical analysis of our dataset, and furthermore,
present feature reduction techniques to enhance the classification
performance of existing classification schemes on our dataset.

Director of Data Science (Machine Learning & Computer Vision)

projects.description: This high impact industry project included analysis and detection of statistically Stationary Motion (SM) in unstructured videos such as surveillance cameras. The objective of my work was to remove repetitive activities referred to as SM among the series of signals. Using C++ and Matlab programming I designed an exponential moving average filtering system that was able to distinguish between different types of motion signals in real-time.
projects.title: Big Data Analysis for Networked Videos

member.occupation: Director of Data Science (Machine Learning & Computer Vision)
Professor of Machine Learning & Robotics and Co-Director of Manchester Centre for Robotics and AI (University of Manchester); ERC Advanced grant holder

projects.description:
During this European funded fellowship I conducted a cognitive experiment that simulated human gaze patterns. The goal of the experiment was to incorporate human inspired fovea vision for the humanoid robot (iCub) that had the ability to perform tasks as a 3-year-old child. 
The work with the robot simulator required C++ programming tools in Linux environment.
projects.title: Robotics for Development of Cognition (RobotDoc)

projects.description: My 2 years of experience working with the team of Computer Systems and Security included statistical analysis of the big data set generated at Alcatel-Lucent Bell labs in Naperville, IL for feature reduction to enhance classification accuracy of anomalous Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) messages. SIP is an important network protocol responsible for multimedia data transfer that significantly affects the security of cellular networks such as 3G and LTE.  As a member of the team I used machine learning analytical tools such as Regression trees, Naïve Bayes and C4.5 classifiers along with my own data reduction techniques to successfully detect anomalous messages among the data. The accuracy of classification using ensemble methods for classification exceeded more than 99.8%.
projects.title: Anomaly Detection of Big Data related to Session Initial Protocol (SIP) Messages
